Of the 24,000 overseas‐born residents of my electorate, the bulk of the most recent arrivals are from non‐English speaking countries such as China and Vietnam. In 15 per cent of Deakin homes, a language other than English is spoken. These are people whose limited command of the English language would have left them particularly vulnerable to exploitation by unscrupulous agents when emigrating to Australia.

In my electorate we have a number of bodies that have been set up to help our immigrants, bodies such as the community council on ethnic issues, migrant resource centres and migrant settlement committees. These particular bodies are working to help newly arrived immigrants settle into our country and to provide the support and service which they deserve. I support the honourable member for Calwell's comments in regard to some of the work of these bodies and we should continue to keep a close eye on their operations and see that they are helping those that they are meant to help.

The 1995‐96 migration program provides for over 58,000 places for family migrants, 23,000 places for skilled migrants and 1,200 places for special eligibility migrants. If we consider the prices many migration agents charge for assistance—and the report Protecting the vulnerable?: the Migration Agents Registration Scheme makes ample mention of this—we see the emergence of a thriving, migration related industry. This in itself is not a bad thing. Prospective immigrants are free to avail themselves of the services of such agents. It is important, however, that the industry is carefully supervised and I believe that the extension of the migration agents registration scheme for another year provides the industry with a regulatory framework.

As the 1995 report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration reveals, there have been cases of abuse and deception in the past. There have been instances in which people have been led to believe that the migration agent has a degree of influence with immigration officials, or that the agent can in some way guarantee the success of one applicant over another—something, of course, which is simply misleading.

In 1995 the committee also came to the conclusion that the migration advice industry was still developing. This is understandable. We are certainly not in the business of denying professional and responsible operators providing advice for a fee the opportunity to assist those either unwilling or unable to approach the bureaucratic complexities of the application. However, it is vital that this industry, like all industries of this sort, create a code of conduct, a type of regulatory structure, with which it can safeguard those who ask for their services.

To extend the migration agents registration scheme to 21 September 1997 means having the opportunity of examining thoroughly the 1995 recommendations of the committee. We must strive to investigate and review these recommendations in a way that will leave no room for the exploitation of those seeking to migrate to Australia.

The preference from my perspective is that the government should be taking a close monitoring role on whether or not these groups can self‐regulate. There are many other groups in our society, professional groups and agencies, that do have good self‐regulatory schemes in operation. I belong to the Australian Psychological Council which, while it is covered by legislation, also has a code of conduct which regulates the profession. It is preferable to go down this way but the migration agents body must prove itself to be able to have strong control over its agents and members.

Many could argue that prospective immigrants should know better than to trust unscrupulous agents, but many immigrants come from countries where paying individuals for influence and not merely for bureaucratic competence is the usual modus operandi. Language difficulties may lead them to believe that paying migration agents is the only option they have, and once again, that makes them vulnerable to exploitation.

The report is quite direct in its acknowledgment of the shortcomings of the scheme. Unfortunately, the scheme itself has not rid Australia of unscrupulous operators and has not adequately protected many immigrants. However, it seems to me that rather than scrapping the scheme we should develop ways of finetuning it. It can be improved.

As the committee noted, the scheme is still in its infancy and has been subjected to a High Court challenge for a large part of its existence. It is vital that we stand behind the scheme throughout this embryonic stage and that we remain committed to the thrust of the scheme—the protection of the most vulnerable members of our society.

I make no secret of the fact that when I arrived in Australia as a young child my family would have been easy prey to the most uncaring elements of our society. My parents were fortunate. They were lucky that they came to this country as sponsored immigrants and they received professional and courteous service in their migration to and settlement in this country. One expects the same level of professionalism, courtesy and faith to be given to newly arrived and prospective immigrants.

These immigrants do not fully comprehend the implications of not being able to speak the language of the country in which they live. It is about vulnerability and about having to trust the untrustworthy, simply because they have a better command of the English language. It has left new arrivals in Australia open to exploitation, with the opportunities to exploit being inversely proportionate to the level of integration in Australian society.

Honourable members would know only too well the emotional frame of mind of those who come to our offices seeking assistance with immigration cases. The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Billson) rightly pointed out in his speech the amount of work that is required, and the honourable member for Calwell noted that we are beholden to keep a careful and watchful eye over the progress of these immigration cases.

In the electorate of Deakin, such cases often take up a large part of our day's work. People tell us stories of families separated by bureaucratic difficulties; of husbands and wives spending years apart. Any member of parliament dealing with such cases would realise that such depth of despair brings with it the vain search for a miracle cure. If they are told that the antidote to their distress can be found and bought, of course they will do it, no matter what the price, no matter how reputable the people who present themselves.

I fully support the extension of the migration agents registration scheme, as does my government. I hope that we will be able to work methodically over the next year to make the scheme as efficient and fair as possible. If we find that self‐regulation is the answer, so be it. I have nothing against the principle of the government keeping its distance from such industries, but there must be an assurance that self‐regulation can provide Australian society with an ethical environment in which we all feel comfortable. If such self‐regulation proves to be premature, let us find other solutions to creating a mature and responsible immigration assistance program.

Finally, I note the comments of the honourable member for Calwell in regard to the article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. I concur with him that some very disturbing elements of anti‐immigration attitudes permeate our society. I believe it is up to us as parliamentarians, as communicators within our electorates, to make sure that the lack of understanding and the untruths that are peddled out there are countered and to make sure that people in our community realise the benefits that generations of immigrants have given to this country. I commend the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Recent contributions—in regard to customs yesterday by the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), and on gun legislation on the previous day by the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Graeme Campbell)—have emphasised to the Australian parliament the lack of knowledge of a variety of sitting members with regard to rural Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset of this debate it is necessary to indicate to those members, and even to a large number of urban members from outside Sydney and Melbourne, some of the realities that preface the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. The Atlas of the Australian People makes a number of very important points about one of the major reasons for this legislation. It notes that in New South Wales, of the Arabic speaking background population, 14.8 per cent of males and 21.5 per cent of females do not speak English at all, or do not speak it very well. In the Turkish population, which is very prevalent in my electorate, 23.8 per cent of males and 32 per cent of females do not speak English at all, or not very well.

It is worth noting in a number of municipalities in the inner west of Sydney the proportion in the population of non‐English speaking background people. In Auburn, 14.3 per cent of the population were born overseas. They are not the relatives of people born overseas; they were actually born overseas themselves in non‐English speaking countries. In Holroyd and Parramatta, the percentage is 4½ per cent. There are now six municipalities in Sydney where over 10 per cent of the population were born in non‐English speaking countries.

In my electorate, 23½ per cent of those born overseas do not speak English very well, and 4½ per cent do not speak it, full stop. It is also interesting to note that in the 1991 census as many as nine per cent of the population had been living in another country five years previously and, of the total population of those born overseas, 33 per cent were born in a non‐English speaking country. This is part of the background of this legislation.

I am very pleased to have served on the joint migration committee over the last three years—I very much regret my inability to play a role in it in the next few years—and to have had the opportunity to participate in this inquiry. It is fair to say that there were differences of emphasis among the political parties on this matter. At the end of the day, a compromise was reached where the then opposition, despite their doubts about the effectiveness of the current migrant agents legislation, felt that it should be given an opportunity of a further few years.

I very much associate myself with this legislation and I think that it is very necessary. Its failings rest not with its being too stringent and too inclined to interfere but with a number of other problems. Firstly, it has had start‐up difficulties in its first few years in dealing with the issue of registration as such, without getting into the actual policing of the industry.

Secondly, I will indicate to some of the other members of this parliament the very different nature of representation in this country. Three of the four people in my office—including me—deal with migration all the time. One person on our staff does the rest of the work: Austudy, veterans affairs and unemployment benefits. So that is some indication of the kind of push factor in migration problems in a number of electorates in Sydney. I see the member for Fowler (Mr Grace) here; he would be in a similar situation.

I think many of us have been guilty because, as lay people lacking a legal background, we see many cases relating to migration agents which we should perhaps refer to this board. I have referred one case involving a lawyer. But we often find that a case is borderline as to whether a complaint would be successful. When it got down to the technicalities of evidence and the issues of fairness, it would be borderline whether at the end of the day you would be successful in getting something done about this person. But the reality out there in society is that there is a need for this kind of board, and that need has many characteristics.

Firstly, as I have indicated, we have an increasing number of people of non‐English speaking background who do not speak English. As the previous speaker, the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) alluded to, the problem is that in many other societies there is a concept that you pay people, and you peddle influence, and you have to know a big‐shot around the place to get somewhere in the political system. In my own case—and I think other members have experienced this—I have found considerable difficulty in convincing migrant people that in this country essentially we operate by laws, by queues and by systems. And you can understand that when people go out to people in the private sector, they feel that it is the same system, that they have got to pay this guy to get somewhere in the process. They do not know what the rules are; they do not know what the system is, and they think that is the way it operates.

Equally, we have really got to look at the actual processing times in this country; the levels of appeal; the way in which they allow people to flout the system by spending years here getting points on the board to justify a long‐term stay here. I think that this is a very big problem. I hope that the new government does tackle it, and I think that more effort might have been made during the previous three to six years if there had been a political will in the government. Once again, this is an encouragement for people to use unscrupulous people.

We have all had experience of women coming in and saying that they have launched refugee cases on the basis that Tonga is a patriarchal society and so every female from Tonga should be allowed to stay here. We have had people claiming refugee status because they refused to marry the first person that they were sent out here from Syria to marry. I had one case like this last week. Essentially, the claim is on refugee‐humanitarian grounds—that if she went back to Syria she would be in such dire circumstances in relation to her family that she should be a refugee in this country. And it goes on and on. People are claiming that their cousin's brother‐in‐law's second cousin's mother‐in‐law was shot five years ago in Kabul and therefore the whole family has justifiable refugee claims in this country.

These are the very concrete problems that this system has been set up to combat. There are people out there who lack skills; there are people out there who feel that you must pay to be in the system; there are people out there who very cynically seek to manipulate the system themselves. Let us be honest about it: many of these claimants are just as bad as the people who are operating as agents. They are here basically to exploit Australia's loopholes—to exploit Australia's adherence to international conventions—when they have no justifiable claim.

There are reasons why this system operates. If you read the evidence you will see much reference made to a Springvale community group. Quite frankly, the reference made to those people is indicative of the fact that they were perhaps the only group that came before the committee with any vocal, persistent criticism of the way the system was operating, from the point of view of not cleaning it up. Even they, under cross‐examination, indicated that, whilst they thought there were failures, whilst from their point of view there might have been discouragement of community workers becoming registered, at the end of the day registration, government intervention and assurance were preferable to nothing at all.

BREAK.PARA: It is worth citing some of the evidence that the committee received. On page 53 of the report, at paragraph 3.53, it noted:

A common theme in submissions was that regulation of the migration advice industry is necessary to ensure consumer protection and the maintenance of appropriate standards within the industry. IARC, for example commented:
. . . a regulatory scheme is necessary to support the reputable people working in this area as well as to eradicate the unscrupulous and incompetent operators.
Further, at paragraph 3.54, it noted:
In some submissions, it was argued that regulation of migration advisers is required because of the vulnerability of persons seeking immigration advice.

. . . immigration is a field which has some unique features which merit special regulation in that the client base is, more often than not, in a particularly vulnerable position and this is the case even with clients who can speak English fluently and are highly educated.

We all know that up until the Cunliffe case the Law Council of Australia wanted to make themselves special, privileged elements, as usual. The Law Council, at the end of the day, said, `Whilst you should not regulate us—the law profession—because we are so legitimate and trustworthy, you should regulate the others.' So, even from that source, we had an admission that there are major problems in this industry.

There is a need for government intervention, because people are so vulnerable and because the industry attracts the possibility of making quick bucks from people who have no base on which to compare fees. Further, at page 55, our report noted:
Commenting on the experience of its members since the enactment of the Scheme, the IRT—
the Immigration Review Tribunal—
stated:

the quality of advice provided by applicants remains very poor. Many agents are ignorant of the regulations, including those applying to review. Often the written submissions we get are little more than legal nonsense.
I can certainly confirm that from many that I have read. It went on to say:
We continue to see applications lodged through agents which are fatally flawed and therefore doomed to fail.

Essentially, these people do not care whether they are going to fail. They advertise in a particular ethnic publication or series of publications in that community; they have a few people out there pushing their barrow, probably getting a retainer, saying that they are the best person around the place; they win a minority of cases; people talk to their family and friends about the minority of cases; and they are still in business, regardless of their inability to actually function in the system properly and despite the fact that they know that many of their cases are beaten before they start.
At page 61, 3.82, it is noted that:

Statistics obtained by the Committee support a finding that the achievements of the Scheme relevant to its objectives have been chequered. On the positive side, around 600 persons either have been denied the right to practise as migration agents or have decided to withdraw from seeking entry to the industry. In addition, the avenues for developing expertise in migration law have increased noticeably, with various courses and seminars now being conducted at a tertiary level and within the industry itself.

We summed up the situation after speaking to the vast majority of people who make up the industry, including reputable agents, community groups, volunteers, people involved from the legal side of migration, the IRT and the registration board itself. The summary of the situation was that, despite problems, the system was essentially doing something. People have been de‐registered, people have been stopped from entering the field and, more importantly, a large number of people have had second thoughts about trying to get registered when they have seen other people failing. They know that they are probably going to attract attention to themselves by their attempt.

The committee made a number of recommendations for the future. It is worth while noting, when we speculate about the possibility that this industry can regulate itself, its abysmal performance in setting up internal training schemes before this board got off the ground. We now can talk about a variety of courses in universities and in colleges. I have to say that that has been a very big advance, but the sad reality is that when these people had the choice themselves, without government intervention and without oversight from this parliament and the joint migration committee, they were not capable of doing anything at all.

The committee did say that the board should look towards the development of a training module to assist non fee charging organisations, which do not qualify for organisation based registration. There was a suggestion by the committee that we revisit the schedule of registration fees. It is quite clear that the original intent to help country areas by a scheme of fees which gave leeway to those people who are doing less than five cases a year has been widely abused. There were some statistics saying that there had been a very pronounced tendency for people to seek registration under that lower level of fees. In fact, as of June 1994, 39 per cent of agents had used the concessional option, 33 per cent were paying nothing at all, and only 28 per cent were paying full fees. There was a suggestion by the committee that we look at the fee schedule to overcome that abuse.
Importantly, there was also a suggestion that the board be pro‐active in advertising to the ethnic community the nature of the registration process as to the oversight that is here in the system.

The point is made—in recommendation 47—that the Migration Agents Registration Board, if it has got any failings, lacks power or lacks teeth and that the number of sanctions that it can apply to the industry should be widened.The committee unanimously came forward with 49 recommendations all told. To my mind they essentially are going in the right direction to try and ensure that this industry is policed.

In conclusion, I reiterate that this industry, more than most, is not capable of self‐regulation. It has a sorry history of abuse of the system. It has a sorry history of exploitation. There have been attempts to inaugurate cases that have no chance whatsoever in the system, essentially aimed at delaying people's deportation from the country and at increasing the agent's image in a variety of ethnic communities, thus engendering more business. It is a system that exploits the most vulnerable people who feel that they have no other options. I commend the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter, Bob, Jnr, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill, I say not only that the legislation is very necessary but also that without it it is very difficult to see how we can have an intelligent migration program in this country. I come at the issue from an entirely different viewpoint from those of the big cities.

SPEECH.PARA: Telstra have a lovely little map out which says, `We cover 95 per cent of the population with our mobile telephones.' If you get out a compass and protractor and work out the area of land that is covered, it works out to somewhat less than five per cent of the surface area of this country. In one recent initiative we looked at the seven major federal electorates that cover 82 per cent of the Australian land mass and the population, just shaving off some of the edges. For example, in my own electorate, by shaving off the coastal part of that electorate the land mass is still maintained, with just a tiny narrow strip that, of course, contains half the population of the electorate of Kennedy.

By just cutting off those narrow coastal strips you come up with a map that looks very much like the map of Australia. It is just shorn of the coastal edges—and, albeit, a fair proportion of Victoria. But it is 82 per cent of the surface area of this country and it is occupied by some four per cent of the Australian population. But, if you use the Telstra analysis, you end up with 95 per cent of the surface area of the country occupied by 95 per cent of the population. So this is the most congested land on earth—the population of Australia is in the most congested land on earth.

The original Australian population did not go to the seas. The original Australian population, the vast bulk of the people now known as Australians—3½ million of them, if you like; most certainly two million of them—came here during the mining boom. They all went to the mining fields of Australia and then tried to make a living contracting, farming and in various other pastoral pursuits. So I think the migration debate is most relevant to the demographic problems of Australia today.

Let me go back to the map of Australia, with some 90 per cent of the continent being occupied by only about four per cent of the population. People say that it is all desert. I am sad to say that that is a flagrant lie. If you get in an aeroplane at Ingham or Innisfail in North Queensland and fly in that aeroplane in a westerly direction, for about 30 kilometres you will go through a very intensely populated area. Then it will be very doubtful whether you will see from that aeroplane any sign of human habitation for the next 10,000 kilometres. It is empty; there is nobody living there.

For those who say that it is a wasteland, that it is desert, let me say that you would have just flown over 75 per cent of Australia's entire rainfall run‐off. In fact, the first river you will fly across is the Mitchell River, which is the second biggest river in Australia—second to the Murray. Along the Mitchell River it is all flat farming country. It is a very long river, running for some 600—arguably, 700—kilometres. I would argue that the vast bulk of it is farming land. And, to my knowledge, there are not even any station properties that water their cattle there. Not only are there no farms, but even the grazing industry does not use that resource because of the prevalence of crocodiles and the dangers that involves and also because of the mud problems that can lead to cattle getting bogged in poor times and dying there. So most of the river is fenced off.

As I said, you will have flown over 75 per cent of Australia's entire water resources. I make the point that that is not east of the coastal divide; it is not in the high rainfall areas of North Queensland—the super wet belt. I am talking about the other side of the Great Divide that contains 75 per cent of Australia's rainfall run‐off. I think the Ord River in Western Australia is the third or fourth biggest river in Australia. So you would have flown over the second and third biggest rivers in Australia. And in relation to the land itself, in that 90 per cent or so of the continent I am referring to, some 70 per cent of the Australia's arable land is in that part of Australia that is totally unpopulated.

One of the reasons that land is unoccupied at the present moment is that we are on a down cycle because the population in western and inland towns in Australia has been declining. Let me take the example of western Queensland. The figures do not encompass the south‐west—which has probably been hit worse than the central west and the mid‐west, which is to outsiders the north‐west of Queensland. In the north‐west and central west of the state, our average population losses over the last 25 years are in excess of 38 per cent for all those shires. In other words, 40 per cent of the population of inland Australia has left.

The rate at which the population is leaving has increased and is increasing. The rate at which we are depopulating all of the land mass of Australia is rapidly increasing. Not only does that impose immense problems in the outback but it also imposes immense strain upon governments which have to provide extra services and facilities in the already overcrowded cities of Australia. If we were able to get people to move back there, the cost of providing infrastructure would be negligible because the infrastructure was put there for populations twice the size of today's population. The cost of putting people on the ground out there is absolutely negligible.

That brings me to the legislation before us today. Let me take the example of a town like Aramac: it has lost more than half its population. Some 20 years ago, it was twice as big as it is today. It does not have a doctor. For any government to say that it is not allowed to have a doctor is not only improper but also the very antithesis of good government. People will die in the Aramac‐Muttaburra area because they do not have a resident doctor.

At the present moment, we can ring up a migration agent and get the agent to deliver a doctor to us. By the time I make this speech, I hope that has, in fact, happened. If it has not happened, I hope it is in the process of happening. Without the migration agent we would have enormous difficulties. In fact, at one stage in the mid‐west region of North Queensland, we were down three doctors and the health department blithely told us continually that it could not secure doctors for us. In fairness to it, in those days there were no migration agents; we could not ring anyone and ask them to send us a doctor. Since the migration agents have come into existence, we have someone to ring: we can ask them to send us a doctor.

This marvellous facility of migration agents which now exists is being crippled. I must pay some tribute to Al Grassby because he coined the phrase `demographic immigration'. He put forward a very important concept. Sadly, his actions in government did not meet his rhetoric. There was a huge gulf between what he promised and what he delivered. Unfortunately, he paid the political price for that. Let us remember his good point, his coining of the phrase `demographic immigration'. He said that whilst there are parts of Australia where immigration may be a mixed blessing there are parts of Australia that desperately need those migrants. In fact, in parts of Australia people will die because of the present immigration laws in Australia that prevent us from getting a doctor to come to Australia.

Whilst undoubtedly the government has the right to say who can and who cannot come into Australia, we say to the government of Australia that if we ring a migration agent and he says, `We have a doctor who is prepared to go to Aramac', you have no right to say to us that we cannot have that doctor come into this country. If you say that to us then let the death of people be upon your conscience. Let me actually quote the figure. Without a resident doctor, every two years one person will die who would not have died had we had a resident doctor for every 1,000 people in a community. In the Aramac‐Muttaburra area we still have 1,000 people, so every two years the government can take upon its conscience the death of some person because of laws which are totally inappropriate to the problems that exist today.

While I have chosen the example of a doctor, in places like Cloncurry the temperature can reach 126 degrees Fahrenheit during summer months: that is indoors. Ground temperatures can reach close to 200 degrees Fahrenheit. In these places, which are some of the hottest places on earth, an airconditioner is not a luxury, it is an absolute necessity. If we have not got a refrigeration mechanic or an airconditioning mechanic to repair our refrigerators or our airconditioners then we are in very desperate trouble. We need plumbers, we need steel fabricators, we need TV repairmen, we need auto‐electricians and in some towns we need electricians and mechanics for our cars. We have none of these people.

The present rules really prevent us from bringing these people into Australia. If the rules say we have too many electricians in Australia I accept those rules. But if we have advertised in the paper and we cannot get an electrician to go to Julia Creek or to Blackall or Barcaldine or Muttaburra then I say, once again, that the rules must be changed. If we were to modify them so that a person could agree to go to that place for some two or three years and then earn the right to become a permanent Australian citizen and go where he likes I think that they would be very good rules. If a person has lived in a community such as Julia Creek for two years and he has made his home and his friends there he tends to stay there.

The immigration department provides us with one of the great answers to one of the saddest occurrences in Australian life today. This country was culturally and economically born in these outback areas. In fact I have the great privilege of representing in the federal parliament Winton, the place where Qantas was founded, and Cloncurry, where our most famous Australian song Waltzing Matilda was written. The Labor movement, which even for people on my side of the House was one of the greatest contributors to the nation as we know it today, was also founded in the Blackall‐Barcaldine area. Many good things in this nation today come from outback North Queensland.

The very heartland of this nation's identity is being made bereft of Australians and those that are living there are being forced out at a great and increasingly greater speed. People do not want to stay there because life is so harsh and it is almost impossible to get a refrigerator or a motor car fixed on a station property. Even to get plumbing done on a station property these days is very difficult. Probably 100 towns in my electorate are bereft of all of the services which we take for granted if we live in a city or even in a coastal town. Plumbers, electricians and refrigeration and airconditioning mechanics are normal everyday services without which society cannot continue to operate.

There is a provision which I applaud where 100 people are allowed into Australia under a trial program called the regional migration scheme. It is an excellent scheme but it badly needs to be changed in a number of ways. The most important way it needs to be changed is that there must be a job for these people to go to. It does not allow them to purchase a business and go to where that business is. It does not allow them to set up a new business in these areas. Let us take the example of an auto‐electrician in a town like Hughenden.

There is no garage in Hughenden that is big enough to employ an auto‐electrician. But the two, three or four garages in the area would, between them, greatly appreciate the services of an auto‐electrician. It may be that Hughenden has secured the services of an auto‐electrician—but I know that in years past we had grave difficulty trying to secure an auto‐electrician for that town. There is no‐one there big enough to employ him, but collectively there is probably the work for two or three auto‐electricians in that town. So the scheme is really of very limited value.

We are so small in so many towns now that nobody employs anyone. There is no such thing as an employee; they do not exist any more. There are only self‐employed people in these towns and the regional migration scheme does not presently allow for self‐employed people to come into the country. So the public servants, the ministers and governmental people who have been involved in bringing this scheme forward have done a very great and laudable job for their country. We have tried it out and realise now that it should be extended in certain areas and that self‐employment is a provision that must be included in modifications to this scheme.

The migration agents are vitally important to the scheme because obviously the people in Aramac or Muttaburra or Blackall have not got access to securing people from overseas. It would be hopeless if they had to chase those people overseas themselves. They desperately need the migration agents as an integral part of any program of repopulating our country.

There is another point I wish to make about the regional migration scheme. If the government is still worried about whether these people are going to stay there or take off, then if these people buy a business or a house in these towns clearly they are showing a great commitment. It is very difficult to sell a business or a house from these towns. So if people still feel strongly that we should not widen the regional migration scheme, if you put that provision in that surely would guarantee that these people would stay there for a certain period of time.

We allow millions of people to come into this country every year under certain terms and conditions, such as holiday and visa arrangements of various types. If you say to me that we cannot allow these people to come into the country as migrants under this condition because they might just leave Julia Creek and go to Brisbane and then we would not be able to find them, I say that you are letting three, four or five million people into this country every year under conditions which you cannot possibly police. Exactly the same argument applies to the person here on a holiday visa: he can decide to just live permanently in Brisbane and you cannot get rid of him.

So, surely, it is untenable to use that argument against allowing a thousand or two thousand families into Australia each year under a widened regional migration scheme such as I am putting forward here because you are allowing not two or three thousand but five or six million people into the country every year and taking a risk with them. So why not take the risk where there is great social benefit to Australia via a regional migration scheme?

Finally, I would like to say that we need a great widening of the regional migration scheme to allow for self‐employed people to come in and a lowering of the conditions under which they are allowed into the country at present, vastly freeing up and liberalising those conditions. We need to keep migration agents. The alternative is to watch Australia become less and less populated and the great resources that God has given to all of us not being utilised at all. We have no moral right to hold on to land that we are not using. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Andrew, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDREW THOMSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my task to sum up the debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996, in the absence of the minister, Mr Ruddock, who is otherwise engaged in the cabinet. Whilst I had a reasonably busy diary this morning, I am very glad he did ask me to perform this task on his behalf because, having sat here for the last 40 minutes or so, I have been fascinated to hear the different perspectives on immigration from different members of the House of Representatives. One perspective was that of Mr Ferguson, the member for Reid, who represents, as I do, a very urban part of this country. Another was that of my friend Mr Katter, the member for Kennedy, who represents the opposite end of the spectrum and perhaps the most regional or rural electorate in the country. It was interesting to hear the different perspectives and the different values that they brought to this debate on behalf of their constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate has also brought out a fundamental difference in philosophies between the two sides of our parliament—the government and the opposition. When my friend the member for Reid talked about self‐regulation as it applies to the migration agents registration scheme, MARS, and his doubts about the efficacy of it, it struck me once again that you find distilled in the forums of this parliament this fundamental philosophical difference between the two sides. But, that said, something the government welcomes in particular is the atmosphere of bipartisanship that applies to this issue.

The member for Denison (Mr Kerr), the shadow minister, who has been aggressive in his criticism of the government in recent times, has shown a very welcome change of attitude in joining with us in dealing with this bill. It is no surprise to me, as a member representing a Sydney electorate and an habitual reader of the Sydney Morning Herald who has read the details of the survey published there this morning—parts of which I must admit I found disappointing. But it is worth reflecting for a little while on the history of political debate about immigration in English speaking democracies.

The first instance I came across, in a history of British politics in the first decade of this century, was in reading of an election campaign that took place in 1905. The Conservative or Unionist Prime Minister Arthur Balfour was opposed by Campbell‐Bannerman and, more particularly, by David Lloyd George of the British Liberal Party. During that campaign, the issue of Chinese labour being used in the mines of South Africa arose. David Lloyd George went to great lengths in parts of middle‐England to beat up the notion that some of this Chinese labour might be imported to work in the coal mines and tin mines of Wales and therefore would put good, solid Welsh miners out of a job.

It is sad to note that David Lloyd George and his colleagues won that election, not perhaps specifically on that issue. But that is the first time I can recall the issue being raised of foreign immigration and the doubts in the electorate about its impact on employment—and, as has been the case lately in Australia, on the environment. Thank God, in this country we have strong bipartisanship on this issue, and I hope that that forever obtains.

The member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) raised the issue of whether or not the existing scheme and the complaints and investigatory mechanisms under it were tough enough. He pointed out that, in his view, there had not been enough people excluded from registration or deregistered. I understand that history shows that, of 2,000 registered migration agents in the country at the present time, in the past over 400 unsuitable applicants have been excluded by the board. But this really leads to the fundamental question of whether or not self‐regulation is the way to go with this matter.

The member for Reid was particularly critical of the approach to the registration of migration agents. I think he quoted from the report of the joint committee, saying that there was something special, something particularly vulnerable, about the client base with which this mechanism of registration deals. That is to say that people who have poor English skills, and who in most cases have very low incomes, fall prey very easily to unscrupulous advisers, registered or not, and that therefore there is some urgent need for government supervision in this area.

BREAK.PARA: This set me thinking about my own electorate, where I have a number of different ethnic communities. The biggest one is the Jewish community, which has seen a lot of immigration from parts of the old Soviet Union in recent years. I have watched how they deal with their community and the needs of their own immigrants, potential and otherwise. They apply severe scrutiny to the immigration advisers to whom the relatives of potential immigrants would apply for help. If they find that there is villainy afoot or that someone is misbehaving they are very quick to make sure that that person is shunned or ostracised and that the word goes around the community that such a person should not be used.

This struck me as perhaps the most efficacious approach. If we go too far down the road of government supervision, interference and regulation in this area then you diminish the need for personal effort on behalf of these particular ethnic communities who want to see more immigration of their own folk. The government cannot see, for the moment, any reason to give up on the capacity of these ethnic groups to do something about these problems themselves, rather than engage the federal government to do it on their behalf. That gives some idea of the philosophical approach to self‐regulation that obtains in the government.

The most interesting perspective in the debate, and one that I had not heard before, was that given by the honourable member for Kennedy. He began by describing the geographical reality of his electorate and making the little known point that the second highest area of rainfall run‐off in Australia is inland from Ingham. When school children in Australia are asked the simple question, `Which town has the highest rainfall in Australia?' most of the well‐informed ones answer `Tully'. It is Tully, but the consequence of the run‐off of that rainfall—
Mr Katter interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have more to learn then. Naturally, the consequence of heavy rainfall is heavy run‐off, and that falls inland. But more especially, he made the point that inland Australia has suffered the depletion of 40 per cent of its population in the postwar period, and that much of the opinion that is distilled and broadcast or printed in our news media is formed in the cities—the urban areas of Australia. This is something that is overlooked. Many in the news media, and certainly in a malevolent sense—let me be blunt—often cast people of inland Australia as somehow xenophobic or instinctively resentful of foreign things, and certainly of foreign immigration.
—Just the opposite is true.

—In fact, the opposite is the case. Perhaps one of their more noteworthy and colourful representatives in this parliament made the very blunt point that this is a matter of life and death to a small community. In any community, be it a small suburb in a city or a small hamlet in a part of rural Australia, a basic need—after air, water and food—is a doctor, because they fall sick from time to time. The only source of this sort of vital service is, in fact, Australia's immigration program. If they are such xenophobes, if they bitterly resent anything from the outside world, then how come their most colourful member is on his feet in the parliament begging for more immigration?
—That is agreed. I am not too worried about where they come from either!
—Perhaps I am putting it a little simply, but the point he was trying to make was that there is an obvious unfair distribution of the existing flows of immigration within Australia.
—Hear, hear!

—Mr Grassby's multisyllabic phrase `demographic immigration' is probably best summed up, in the sort of language that a member of the House of Representatives uses in his or her travels, as `what you need is more of a fair go in terms of the immigration program.' The government, in the famous phrase of Sir Humphrey's, is fully seized of that. I will make sure that on the next occasion I have to discuss these matters with the minister, Mr Ruddock, I put that point to him privately, but as forcefully, perhaps, as the member for Kennedy did in his contribution.

BREAK.PARA: To sum up the essential points, the government welcomes the opposition's contribution to this debate. It welcomes in particular the bipartisanship that has obtained and continues to obtain about immigration matters. We reiterate our desire for an approach of self‐regulation, or enhanced self‐regulation, to this type of scheme. But we will not hurry to do this. In most things—whether it is a decision of the cabinet or whether it is hitting a golf ball—if it is done too quickly, it is usually done very badly. There are many proverbs, metaphors, whatever you like, to illustrate that important point—that, if you do something too quickly, you usually muck it up. There is an urgent need, as the gentleman from Kennedy has pointed out, for this to be dealt with efficaciously. As soon as I can find the minister, I will make that point to him.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Mr Fahey:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Gareth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the opposition does not oppose this measure. It arises as a consequence of a decision by the government to change the salary structure for ministers, legislation to achieve which has already been passed. Due to the design of the superannuation arrangements for Commonwealth parliamentarians, cutting the existing salaries of non‐cabinet ministers would impact on the superannuation pensions of some existing parliamentary superannuants and also on the entitlements of some current members.

SPEECH.PARA: The reduction would arise for current superannuants with non‐cabinet ministerial experience because the superannuants are paid with reference to their past service and also to the current salary levels that are applicable to that service. There would, therefore, be a reduction in pension payment from the pre 2 May level, which would continue until such time as, if ever, non‐cabinet ministers' salary increased back to the pre 2 May level. Similarly, the value of the superannuation entitlements of current members with non‐cabinet ministerial experience would be reduced should they retire or die prior to the non‐cabinet ministerial salary again returning to the pre 2 May level.

This bill proposes to insulate existing superannuants from the effects of the salary reduction basically by maintaining current pension payments and maintaining the value of the superannuation entitlements of existing members by ensuring that the formula remains as it previously was. In short, there is a general principle, accepted by all governments, that changes to superannuation should `grandfather' existing recipients. Adherence to that principle simply means that the rules should not be changed retrospectively to the detriment of superannuants. This legislation abides by that principle, and for this reason the opposition does not oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews, Kevin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation is a matter of equity, as has been pointed out by the honourable member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans). It precludes a retrospective diminution in benefits already accrued to retired and serving members of parliament. The existing provisions of the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act base retiring allowances—that is, parliamentary pensions—on the salaries payable from time to time for parliamentary service and in respect of offices held as ministers of state and other office holders of the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The reduction in salary for non‐cabinet ministers, which came into effect on 11 March this year, would have had two effects. First, it would have reduced some pensions payable to former coalition and opposition members—or to widows or widowers of former members—who had been non‐cabinet ministers. Second, it would have reduced accrued benefits of some coalition and opposition members who previously had had non‐cabinet ministerial service.

The bill will prevent those reductions by freezing the benefit levels at pre‐reduction levels. Once the salaries of non‐cabinet ministers increase and overtake pre‐reduction salaries, benefits will be increased in line with future salary increases. Similarly, the bill would also prevent any reductions in members' accrued superannuation benefits if the salaries on which the accrued benefits are based were to decrease in the future.

The prevention of a reduction in accrued superannuation benefits is consistent with the intent of the superannuation regulatory legislation. As I said at the outset, this is a matter of equity for former members of parliament and current members of parliament who have served in ministerial but non‐cabinet positions.

It was the desire of the government to indicate through its principal decision in relation to what may be regarded as two tiers of ministerial salaries that the salaries paid to cabinet ministers be of a higher level than the salaries paid to non‐cabinet ministers. If this piece of legislation had not been passed it would have had adverse consequences on the financial arrangements with respect to superannuation and pensions for those former members of the ministry who were not members of the cabinet. Therefore, there is a real question of equity so far as this legislation is concerned. It is because of the matter of equity that the legislation has been brought in by my colleague the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), whom I am glad to see here. The government is pleased with the opposition's wholehearted support for this measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) has explained, the catalyst for this legislation is the government's decision to reduce the salaries of the 13 so‐called junior ministers by $10,000 each per annum. The consequence of that would have been that the superannuation entitlements of previous ministers, because they are tied to salaries paid to present ministers, would have been reduced commensurately. I support this legislation, if not for any other reason than that if it is not passed it will superimpose, retrospectively, a penalty on previous ministers. I have always been consistent in my very vocal and dedicated opposition to retrospective measures which impose penalties, burdens or other imposts having retrospective effect. The legislation, in my view, is absolutely necessary.

BREAK.PARA: The reason for our talking about it at all is that it arose out of the decision of the government, very early in its term of office, to announce this salary reduction. It was purely and simply a public relations exercise, one which has failed miserably. There is not one elector out there who remembers and, because no‐one remembers, I think it can fairly be said to be the thoughtless action of a new and zealous cabinet.

More than that, it overrides the findings and decisions of the Parliamentary Remuneration Tribunal. The consequence of that for every parliamentarian is that, on the very next occasion that that tribunal ordains that we are entitled to some sort of a salary increase or increment in our allowances, we will be obliged to defend the decision of such a tribunal and thereby be prevented from doing the jobs we were elected to do. We will be put in a position where we have to defend the findings of an independent body established specifically for the purpose of taking the heat out of the question of parliamentary salaries and allowances. It was a foolish decision for that reason as well.

The actual savings to be obtained by the government involve 13 so‐called junior ministers at $10,000 per annum—a gross of $130,000 per annum. If the tax of $63,700 on that at a marginal rate is taken out, plus the Medicare levy of 49 cents in the dollar and the 11 or 12 per cent that the ministers would have had to pay out of the $10,000 had it not been removed from their entitlement, the amount is something in the vicinity of $60,000 or $70,000 per annum. That decision smacks of populism at its worst.

Given the reasons I have already enunciated, it is hardly worth the candle. It is the decision of a small‐minded, penny‐pinching cabinet which has given it no serious thought, other than the fact that it might be a very popular decision. There can be no other reason for it. It is going to make no contribution whatsoever to the $8 billion Beazley black hole that the government likes to claim as justification for—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't think you believed that.

—I do, I am afraid. I am sorry to disappoint you, my friend. I do believe it. To suggest that whatever their salary was before the reduction of $10,000 each was too much is absolute rubbish, in the opinion of most people in the community. Most fair‐minded people in the community do not jib at ministers getting fair remuneration, any more than they jib at members of parliament getting fair and reasonable remuneration. The dedicated few out there will jump on to these decisions and we will be faced with having to defend a decision taken in haste, thoughtlessly, and with a view to garnering some sort of adulation from the masses, adulation which simply is not forthcoming and never was going to be forthcoming.

BREAK.PARA: So I say to the Minister for Finance that, whilst this legislation is necessary as a consequence of that decision, it was a stupid decision and one that I hope is never repeated. This legislation has a one‐off effect, as we know, because it only applies to the salaries of those 13 ministers. In the future, if you want to do something along those lines, you are going to have to go through the whole exercise again. But I hope you do not bother. I hope you would give it away, because you have won no medals whatsoever out there. The savings involved are petty, the decision itself was petty and the motivation for it, as far as I can see, was unworthy of a new government setting out to do the difficult things and tackle the difficult areas of spending where big money is involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable members for their contributions to this debate. In closing debate on the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Amendment Bill, I simply wish to reiterate what I stated earlier in the debate: that the reduction in salary for non‐cabinet ministers would have had unintended consequences. It would have had an effect of reducing the pensions payable to certain former coalition and ALP members who had been non‐cabinet ministers, or, where they had died, to their widows. The accrued benefits of some serving members from both sides of politics who previously had non‐cabinet ministerial service would have been reduced.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill will prevent these reductions by freezing the benefit levels until the actual salary payable to non‐cabinet ministers overtakes the pre‐reduction salary. Benefits will then increase in line with future salary increases. Similarly, the bill would also prevent any future reductions in pensions and serving members' accrued benefits if the salaries on which those benefits are based were to decrease in the future. The amendments contained in the bill will maintain the level of expenditure on current pensions payable under the scheme. I thank those who have contributed to the debate and look forward to the bill's speedy passage in the other place.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH LEGISLATION (POWERS OF INVESTIGATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 28 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill 1996 sets the scene for a cooperative approach to legislation in this parliament. The legislation before us today was initiated in the last parliament and was supported by the coalition at that time. Today we are honouring that support and invite the now opposition's continuing support of these amendments concerning investigative powers held by the Health Insurance Commission.

These powers permit the Health Insurance Commission to obtain information and conduct searches in order to monitor compliance with Medicare guidelines. They also enable the commission to execute search warrants and seize material for the purposes of evidence. The legislation will enable the continuation of these powers following the encouraging report that came from the Australian National Audit Office which was tabled in this place on 22 May. The Impact of sunset clause on investigatory powers follow-up audit will confirm that the safety mechanisms employed by the HIC have ensured that powers have been used correctly.

By repealing section 2 of the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994 and item 68 of schedule 1 of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act (No. 3) 1995, this legislation will enable the Health Insurance Commission to continue to conduct investigations and prepare prosecutions against providers and requesting practitioners who do abuse the system.

Section 2 of the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994 specifically provides that the entire act should cease to have force on and from 1 July 1996. The sunset clause resulted from concerns expressed before the Senate Standing Committee

BREAK.PARA: on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that the broad ranging powers provided for in the act offered scope for corruption and abuse of delegated authority by officers of the Health Insurance Commission. It allowed for a reasonable period of time, roughly two years, for parliament to make a considered judgment about whether the powers had been abused in any way by the Health Insurance Commission.

No evidence of improper activity by the Health Insurance Commission has arisen during this period. Moreover, the conferred powers have improved the commission's ability to effectively detect and deal with Medicare non-compliance and fraud. It is, therefore, important that those powers now be preserved in order to give full effect to the role and function of the Health Insurance Commission as a regulatory body over Medicare practices and fraud.

Similarly, item 68 of schedule 1 of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act (No. 3) 1995 provides that item 66 and the amendments made by item 66 of schedule 1 of that act cease to be in force from 1 July 1996.

Item 66 ensures procedural fairness in relation to the seizure of evidential materials for the purposes of investigating Medicare fraud and overservicing. It does so by imposing an obligation on authorised officers or officers assisting the commission to return material seized for the purposes of evidence in the course of conducting searches and investigations when the reason warranting the seizure no longer exists or a decision is made not to use the material in evidence. The item, therefore, aims to protect the interests and privacy of a medical practitioner who may come under investigation for fraud.

This bill establishes that certain measures should be kept in place to allow the continued control and enforcement of compliance with Medicare benefit guidelines. This bill aims to retain the delegation of powers which have proven, on a trial-like basis, to be efficient, substantive and pertinent to the role of the Health Insurance Commission.

In the absence of any evidence that the powers delegated by the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994 have been or are prone to being abused and distorted, the sunset clause incorporated into that act should be repealed. In order to preserve a follow‐on provision in the interests of fairness and individuals' rights, the sunset clause incorporated into the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act (No.3) 1995 relating to item 66 should also be repealed.
Without these amendments the sunset clause would take effect on 1 July 1996, thus seriously undermining the ability of the HIC to prevent, and prosecute against, Medicare fraud.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am pleased to be able to advise you and the minister at the table that the opposition will support this legislation. As the minister has outlined, it is a package that seeks to remove a sunset clause that otherwise would take effect on 1 July l996. Any time sunset clauses are discussed, I am reminded of an incident that took place when the former Lord Mayor of Sydney was a candidate for the New South Wales Legislative Assembly. As many of us have had to do when seeking preselection, he had to appear before the members of the Liberal Party in the Manly area, and one of the questions he had from the floor without any warning was whether he was in favour of sunset clauses in legislation. His reply was that he did support daylight saving!

SPEECH.PARA: There is now a better understanding of what sunset clauses are and this particular clause was inserted in this piece of legislation by the Liberal and National parties. At the time the Labor government did not oppose the clause being inserted because we wanted the legislation carried, but we were confident that these extra powers would allow the Health Insurance Commission to ensure that proper investigations into any allegations of fraud or overservicing did take place. Those measures were the result of close consultation with the AMA.

The former Labor government thought that there were difficulties in the previous process of investigation. Before the amendments were introduced by the former health ministers, Senator Richardson and Ms Lawrence, the process was that the Health Insurance Commission would carry out the preliminary investigations. I understand they would be referred to the Australian Federal Police perhaps for search warrants or for other information to be collected. Then, if it got high enough on the AFP's list of priorities, a brief would be referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions before, ultimately, action might be taken in the courts.

As a result of the powers that were given to the Health Insurance Commission that are under threat from the sunset clause, the legislation ensures that the Health Insurance Commission can use search warrants or can use its powers to collect the information that otherwise would have been required by AFP processes. We still believe that these measures are necessary for the Health Insurance Commission to obtain the information it needs.

We understand that there is always a bit of controversy when you are talking about giving any government organisation the power to search or to seize documents. We only want them to be used, and we have always argued that they should only be used, where there is a serious risk that evidence may be destroyed. It is understandable that there were concerns about privacy issues and the possible abuse of these powers. That is why we have been reading with interest the Australian National Audit Office's audit of the powers and the way the Health Insurance Commission has used them.

The audit's purpose was to ascertain whether the enhanced investigatory powers had improved the commission's ability to investigate and prosecute fraud and other offences under the health legislation and to determine whether the commission had used the powers with integrity in a professional manner and in accordance with the legislation.
The ANAO concluded:
The enhanced powers have improved the commission's ability to conduct investigations and prepare prosecutions.
Secondly:
Without the powers of this kind the ability of the commission to conduct investigations and prepare prosecutions would be impaired.
And thirdly:
The commission is using the enhanced powers in accordance with the legislation and in a professional manner.

I think that, first of all, the parliament should be grateful that the ANAO has been able to conduct that audit and provide such a warm endorsement of the Health Insurance Commission in the way that it has used these powers. In some ways, it is perhaps a pat on the back to former health ministers, Senator Richardson and Ms Lawrence, for being prepared to provide these powers to the Health Insurance Commission.
I was interested to read the other day that the federal president of the AMA, Dr Weedon, was not quite convinced. The 3 June edition of Australian Medicine says:

BREAK.PARA: AMA federal president Dr David Weedon said that it was too early to form an opinion and that at the very least the sunset period should be extended by another year. `The whole thing should be kept under review, and no decision should be taken for at least another 12 months,' he said.
Admittedly, he does go on to say:
`The AMA believes that fraud is fraud and we have no sympathy for anybody who commits fraud.'

I think that the ANAO audit is sufficient evidence to persuade me, and obviously the government, that we do not need to give the Health Insurance Commission another one-year trial. We think that there is sufficient evidence that the Health Insurance Commission can be trusted with these powers.

I would also like, at this point, to note that during the election campaign the Liberal‐National parties in their election policy on health said that they would make the Medicare system work as efficiently as possible and that a coalition government would also direct the Health Insurance Commission to step up its efforts to identify and prosecute overservicing and fraud. Perhaps in the summing up the minister might indicate whether this policy commitment means that the government might be considering introducing further changes to the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Act 1994. Perhaps she and the government might give consideration to undoing some of the amendments to the original bill which, I understand, were moved by the then opposition. Some words, according to the Health Insurance Commission, have emasculated the Health Insurance Commission's capacity to monitor fraud. I would strongly support the government giving some consideration to these issues even if there is no answer today. If they are to meet the commitment that they gave during the election campaign they might have to take more account of the advice that the Health Insurance Commission has given on previous occasions.
For all of those reasons, it is a pleasure to be in the chamber today, supporting the government's legislation. I wish the minister well with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have a number of constituencies to represent in a formal and informal sense, you might say, I felt it was important to speak in support of the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill 1996. Prior to the introduction of Medibank during the term of the Whitlam government, the concepts of medical overservicing and fraud were all but unheard of. Whilst the virtues of Australia's universal health insurance scheme have been widely promulgated and are now an entrenched part of Australia's health and political landscape, attempts by successive governments to deal with abuse of the system still remain focused entirely on the supply side of the equation.

SPEECH.PARA: Wildly spectacular and invariably inaccurate claims have been made at different times in the past about the extent of alleged medical overservicing and fraud. The previous government even factored in a figure of $300 million per year in its 1993 budget forward estimates. By the time he retreated from both the health portfolio and the parliament, the former health minister, the then Senator Graham Richardson, was prepared to admit that nobody really knew what figure to place on it but that `it might not be much at all'.

In his 1992 annual report, the Auditor‐General called for enhanced legislative powers for the Health Insurance Commission to tackle overservicing and fraud. This bill relates specifically to fraud. Thankfully, it is, as we have just heard from the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), a bipartisan issue. The powers embodied in this legislation allow the Health Insurance Commission to obtain information and conduct searches in order to monitor compliance with Medicare guidelines.

BREAK.PARA: During the latter part of 1993, when I was the President of the Australian Medical Association, we assisted the then minister to develop legislation—which is something about which I will make a few comments later—to address inappropriate medical servicing and fraud. The AMA then, as now, supported the transfer to the Health Insurance Commission from the Australian Federal Police of the investigation of alleged fraudulent activity by doctors and patients. Support for such a transfer was based on a frustration shared by both the HIC and the AMA that the Federal Police, having a very broad and difficult range of issues to investigate for prosecution, were often forced to place a low priority on Health Insurance Commission matters, in the context of their arguably more important range of national criminal investigations.

As the legislation transferred significant and wide ranging powers to the Health Insurance Commission, it was considered prudent by both the medical profession and the then government, on the advice of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, that a sunset clause for a reasonable period of time be inserted, to be used to examine whether the powers had been abused in any way by the Health Insurance Commission. It would seem that, in the two years since it was enacted, neither the Australian National Audit Office nor the AMA has found that the safety mechanisms employed by the HIC, as described in the bill, have been abused.

It is the view of the government—as we have heard from the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) and from Parliamentary Secretary Woods in the second reading speech in the Senate—that the mechanisms should now be preserved by repealing section 2 of the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment 1994 and item 68 or schedule 1 of the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act (No. 3) 1995. Section 2 of the health legislation specifically provided that the entire act should cease to have force on and from 1 July 1996.

The powers of investigation which were specifically granted to the HIC in the Health Insurance Amendment Act 1994 are in part IID of the Health Insurance Act 1993. Those powers are summarised as the power to require a person to give information or produce a document; the power to enter and conduct searches of premises without consent of the occupier; the power to search premises, after entry with consent, to take photographs of anything except documents, to inspect and take samples of drugs, substances or ingredients, and to take extracts from any documents but not in relation to clinical details; the power to seize evidential material; the power to apply for a magistrate to issue a search warrant to search premises and seize material; the power to remove things from the premises to determine if they are things that may be seized; the power to seize material not included on the warrant, if reasonably necessary; and the power to return material that is seized.

Given the significance of these powers, it is important that honourable members appreciate the safeguards that exist on those powers, because they are, as you can see, quite considerable. In order to obtain a warrant, a document called in information must be sworn on oath. The information must set out the grounds for suspecting that there may be particular evidential material at the premises, and the magistrate can refuse to issue the warrant if not satisfied that there are reasonable grounds. The warrant is only valid for seven days and must state the purpose, the time when entry is authorised, a description of the material to be seized and whether this includes records containing clinical details. A warrant may also be obtained by telephone in urgent circumstances.

The details of the warrant must be given to the occupier. Patients must be informed, unless prejudicial to the investigation, if clinical details are involved. It is an offence punishable by fine or two years imprisonment to make false or misleading statements in an application for a warrant and/or telephone warrant. A section 8P notice is only valid for 14 days and must be issued on reasonable grounds and does not include the power to inspect clinical records, unless it is the patient who is being required to give the information in relation to a claim that has been made.

The power to issue the 8P notice and the power of entry and seizure by consent or warrant apply to certain offences under the Health Insurance Act 1973, including the making of false or misleading statements in connection with a Medicare claim, knowingly making false statements relating to Medicare benefits, false statements, bribery in relation to the rendering of pathology services, and prohibited practices in relation to pathology services. The penalties for these offences are severe, ranging from fines of up to $10,000 or imprisonment for five years, to both.

Although there are certain safeguards built into the legislation requiring the exercise of these powers, as I have outlined, a lingering concern exists within the medical profession that there is no mechanism for internal review prior to execution of the powers. A person who receives a section 8P notice is not able to apply to the issuing officer for the review of the decision. One of the proposals that the parliament may wish to consider in due course is the establishment of an office of the Health Insurance Commission Ombudsman, who could oversee the use of these powers so that there is an avenue of appeal. In this regard, amongst numerous others, I will be keeping a watchful eye on the consequences to those under investigation of the issuing of section 8P notices.

A further concern put to me by the Australian Doctors Fund and its diligent, hardworking chief executive, Mr Stephen Milgate, is the possibility that these powers could be used in relation to `simple billing errors'. Certainly, section 128A—the making of a false or misleading statement in relation to a claim—could be used as the `relevant sense' in order to exercise those powers. However, looking at the requirements for a section 8P notice and obtaining authorisation for entry with consent or obtaining a search warrant, I find it difficult to envisage that they, in fact, would be exercised in relation to simple errors.

In considering the repeal of the sunset clause in this legislation, honourable members should be aware that, in its submission to the Australian National Audit Office's review, the Australian Medical Association stated:

The Association is not aware of any complaints from members specifically relating to the HIC's use of investigatory powers granted under the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Act 1994.

To elaborate on that, from speaking to the senior officers of the AMA, I understand that, when the association wrote to all of its branches and subsidiary and kindred medical organisations, there was not one concern expressed by any legitimate or mainstream medical organisation under the umbrella of the AMA about the present powers that the act covers.
Equally, the ANAO's report, Impact of sunset clause on investigatory powers: Follow‐up audit, summarised the functioning of the present legislative provisions as follows:

The enhanced powers to investigate fraud and excessive servicing have improved the Commission's ability to conduct investigations and prepare prosecutions. The ANAO considers without powers of this kind, the ability of the Commission to conduct investigations and prepare prosecutions would be impaired. This view has been supported by stakeholders consulted during the audit, and the Commission is using the enhanced powers in accordance with the legislation and in a professional manner.

One concern that is a reasonable one for the parliament to consider is the level of funding that governments actually make available to the Health Insurance Commission for its genuine and legitimate activities in monitoring and covering surveillance of Medicare benefits. If you consider that the budget available is in the vicinity of $11 million to oversee some $7.6 billion in Medicare benefits and another $2.3 billion in pharmaceutical benefits, I think some consideration could, and perhaps should, be given by government at some stage to increasing, at the very least, the money available for surveillance. That would be in the interests of both patients and the medical profession.

In concluding, I urge honourable members to refrain from cheap and unwarranted attacks on the integrity of the medical profession, fuelled in some instances by the politics of envy and mediocrity.
