Alleged medical overservicing is a term that is almost impossible to define, except by a group of the doctor's own peers. The previous government, to its great credit, passed legislation which enables processes of peer review to determine what excessive servicing may or may not be. In fact, I recall at the time we were working with the government on this legislation and trying to bring our membership along with us—which is not an easy task, I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker—that defining overservicing is a bit like pornography: you cannot define it, but you know it when you see it.

Fraud is quite a different matter—and the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) has just alluded to this in quoting comments from the immediate past president of the AMA. When governments fund medical services and patients accept government funding, the powers of investigation of alleged fraudulent behaviour are necessarily substantial. Apart from repealing the sunset clause in this act, it is long past time that this parliament considered, in a bipartisan way, mechanisms for addressing the unsustainable growth in demand for publicly funded medical services which endangers the present Medicare arrangements far more than the improper behaviour of a very small number of doctors who nonetheless need to be brought to justice.

For the benefit of the member for Dobell, I would also remind the House that the Health Insurance Commission indeed did want far more power than was finally given to them in the legislation. They wanted the power to be the policemen; they wanted the power to be the jury and the judge; they wanted to do everything in‐house. They wanted their own people to determine what unnecessary services were and they wanted power unto themselves to investigate and prosecute for fraud. Correctly, in the opinion of the AMA and also of the previous government, that was quite unacceptable. Whilst I am very happy to support this piece of legislation and the removing of the sunset clause, I would not under any circumstances like to see the HIC have more power than it already has. I would, however, like to see them have more resources to do what they are supposed to be doing.

This legislation is also a very good illustration of what can be achieved when governments put aside what I call the class war; when they start to realise that a lot more can be achieved by working with professional organisations in the medical area than working against them. Sometimes some of the language which has been used by some representatives of the previous government in particular in describing doctors is, I can only say, not helpful to developing this kind of cooperative approach.

I would also like to pay tribute to one of my constituents—the former health minister, Mr Graham Richardson. In paying tribute to him I know I will not attract his vote, because he is always a very truthful man and he said that he would go to the grave voting Labor. I am sure he will do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said that once, Brendan, didn't you?

—I didn't ever say that. I would like to say, though, that when he was the minister for one year it was a period when a great deal was achieved. It was a pity that Mr Richardson chose to leave the parliament when he did. Had his successor taken an approach along the lines that he had taken, I suspect I would not be speaking to you now as the member for Bradfield.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I just want to respond to the question put by the shadow minister. As I am sure the shadow minister will realise, it was really important that we brought this amending legislation before the House at this time and expedited it as quickly as possible so that the work of the Health Insurance Commission can proceed without interruption. I think you will agree that that is the most appropriate course of action at this time. However, I am sure that my colleague the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) will be keeping a close watching brief on the operation of this act and that, if necessary, it will come under parliamentary scrutiny at a later date.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted also to say that I heard the shadow minister's comment that he was satisfied with the audit report. It was a very thorough report, as one would expect from an audit report. I think it is heartening to know that there was good and close consultation with the stakeholders in this area and that no stakeholder consulted expressed any concern about the inappropriate use of the enhanced powers by the commission. The AMA was one of those consulted and it responded that the association had not been made aware of any complaints from members specifically relating to the HIC's use of the investigatory powers granted under the act.

We can be certain that it has been thoroughly gone into and that we can confidently pass this piece of legislation through the House today and allow the Health Insurance Commission to get on with the task that it has to do in ensuring that it puts a stop to fraud and to Medicare practices that the public has a right to expect will not continue.

We do have a duty to the public. The public has a right to expect that we will ensure adequate powers are available to the Health Insurance Commission so that it can carry out all the investigations that need to be carried out and, as I said, put a stop to abuse of practices and to any Medicare fraud that might be taking place. It is of great cost to the community and it is unfair to those providers in the community who are doing the right thing.
I commend this bill to the House. I would like to thank honourable members for their contributions and their cooperation in expediting this matter today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1996

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill amends the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990. It will enhance the international leadership role Australia has established in the fight against the use of prohibited drugs in sport. It will allow the Australian Sports Drug Agency to work more cooperatively with international sports organisations to conduct drug tests, both at major sporting events and out of competition, on an annual basis.

The bill will also ensure that this country's successful anti-doping program operates even more efficiently and effectively. Drug testing programs will continue to deter athletes from using drugs while at the same time ensuring the rights of athletes who undergo drug testing will not be compromised. Most importantly, this bill will reduce the likelihood of legal challenges which may result from an athlete returning a positive drug test.

The Australian Sports Drug Agency, by way of background, was established in response to the recommendations of the then Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I acknowledge the considerable efforts of several of my colleagues on that committee in successfully advocating the need for such an agency, which has always had strong bipartisan support. The coalition sport and recreation policy, Encouraging players—developing champions, demonstrates the continuing support of this side of the parliament to the eradication of drugs in sport and the work of the agency.

I am pleased to say that since the establishment of the Australian Sports Drug Agency this country has positioned itself as a leader in the international fight against doping, a fact recognised throughout the world. Since its establishment, the Australian Sports Drug Agency has conducted more than 15,000 drug tests and has implemented comprehensive education programs throughout schools and sports in this country. It has also developed guidelines for drug education for use by the international sports community.

These programs have been remarkably successful. During the past year, for example, more than 3,000 drug tests have been undertaken by ASDA and more than 99 per cent of tests were `drug free'. The Australian Sports Drug Agency has also been successful in working with professional sports leagues to conduct testing programs on a fee for service basis. All these drug tests are analysed by the internationally accredited Australian Sports Drug Testing Laboratory in Sydney. This laboratory will analyse about 2,000 drug tests during the two to three weeks of the Sydney Olympic Games.

In recent years the Australian Sports Drug Agency has played an increasingly successful role in working internationally so that our athletes can compete on a more level playing field. Drug testing programs have been implemented cooperatively in the international sports of athletics, cycling, rowing, weight‐lifting, swimming and gymnastics. During the past 12 months the number of out-of-competition drug tests conducted by international sports has increased by almost 50 per cent. In its relatively brief history the Australian Sports Drug Agency has carried out the drug testing programs for the world swimming championships, the South‐East Asian Games, the world weight‐lifting championships and a host of other major international sporting events.

The government has also entered into anti-doping agreements with other countries, including the United Kingdom, Canada, France, New Zealand and Norway. This multilateral agreement will lead to the establishment of an international benchmark for testing programs utilising an internationally recognised system of accreditation and certification. Australia was also the first non-European country to accede to the Council of Europe Anti-Doping Convention, which aims to harmonise anti-doping programs between countries. Most significantly, following a request from the Chinese anti-doping authorities, the Australian Sports Drug Agency is assisting China to establish its own sports drug agency.

BREAK.PARA: These substantial international achievements are only possible because of our strong and successful national anti-doping programs. The Australian Sports Drug Agency, in concert with the Australian Sports Commission and all state and territory departments responsible for sport and recreation, has coordinated the development of a national drugs in sport framework. The framework was endorsed by all Commonwealth, state and territory ministers for sport in November 1995.

There was common recognition across all states and territories that achieving the objectives of this anti-doping initiative will lead to the following matters: athletes around Australia being exposed to consistent drug testing programs; opportunities for all elite athletes to receive sport drug education; an emphasis on promoting the ethos that the use of drugs to enhance sports performance is cheating; and improvements in the expertise of government and sport to develop effective drugs in sport policy.

This government fully endorses those objectives and commits itself to strengthening Australia's strong anti-doping programs through the coordinated action of all governments in the drugs in sport area. The framework recognises the principle of natural justice and the need to respect the rights of individuals. Effective anti-doping programs which deter athletes and their associates from cheating need to recognise that everyone must be treated in a fair and just way. In particular, the framework recognises the rights of young athletes. The development of this framework involved all key players in the sport industry in both the government and non-government sector. It was pleasing to see the Confederation of Australian Sport, which represents more than 100 national sporting organisations, acknowledge the success of this important anti-doping initiative.

This national initiative will be critical in achieving this government's goal of a drug free Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. Australia's strong and committed anti-doping stance was considered a significant factor in winning the right to host the 2000 Olympic Games. However, the Australian sports community remains concerned about the lack of an international level playing field in respect to doping. The success of Sydney in winning the right to host the 2000 Games provides us with a unique opportunity to further the international fight against doping.

As a result of its leadership status and with the spotlight on Sydney 2000, the government is well placed to demonstrate the effectiveness of its domestic anti-doping programs and in so doing advocate to the international sports community the need for a similar stringent and effective effort. This will not only be critical to the sporting and financial success of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games but will reduce the harm to Australian athletes by ensuring that they are able to compete on equal terms. It also has the potential to re-establish the credibility of international sport and provide a launching pad for a drug-free sporting ethos into the 21st century. The bill will help achieve this goal.
The government supports a comprehensive package of measures aimed at pursuing a drug free 2000 Olympic Games. These measures include:
* a drug testing program that targets international athletes competing and training in Australia;
* advocating out‐of‐competition testing programs by international sports federations which target their top athletes on an annual basis;
* drug testing programs by SOCOG at the 2000 Olympics and the test events leading up to the 2000 Games;
* the maintenance of an internationally accredited drug testing laboratory in Australia and continuing research to ensure new doping practices can be detected;
* education programs throughout school and sporting communities;
* anti-doping agreements between Australia and other governments; and
* measures to reduce both the prescribing and illicit supply of performance enhancing drugs.

This package of measures will be implemented by key organisations from the sport, health, education and law enforcement agencies in the government and non-government sectors. The Australian Olympic Committee and the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games—SOCOG—will play a critical role. It is encouraging to see SOCOG has already established its drug testing expert committee with a very strong ASDA involvement.

A drug free Sydney 2000 will require cooperation from international sport. The government is committed to working with the International Olympic Committee, the Australian Olympic Committee, and the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games to achieve this important goal.

This bill and our anti-doping policies are about sportsmen and sportswomen and their right to compete in drug free sport. For this reason, the Australian Sports Drug Agency has made a great effort to understand the concerns of our athletes and to ask them if they think Australia's anti-doping initiatives are achieving success. The Agency's 1995 survey of elite Australian athletes showed that:

* the majority of athletes think it is likely that they will be tested out-of-competition within the next 12 months. Compared to results from previous years these figures show an increased awareness by athletes of their likelihood of being tested;
* there remains a high degree of accord with all aspects of the ASDA testing program, particularly with the sample collection process and the conduct of ASDA personnel;

* Australia's elite athletes are making use of the information services provided by ASDA. Over 80 per cent of these athletes were satisfied with this service which reflects the growing awareness of athletes about drugs in sport issues;

* thirty-two percent of all athletes are aware of international out‐of-competition testing in their sport. This is almost double the percentage reported in 1994. Despite this, athletes still express concern over the effectiveness of testing programs outside Australia; and
* athletes recognise the need for effective sanctions and believe this is critical if athletes are to be deterred from the use of performance enhancing drugs.

The findings from the survey indicate that, while Australia's approach to the drugs in sport issue has been successful, the international drugs in sport situation is still of concern to athletes. In the core areas of drug testing, education and policy work, the indicators that have been collected for four years all confirm the positive impact that has been made and sustained by ASDA in the sporting environment.

Clearly ASDA is making progress towards its mission to ensure that Australian athletes are able to compete in sport which is free from banned doping practices. In pursuit of this goal ASDA will continue to focus on the international drugs in sport situation in the lead‐up to the Sydney Olympics and beyond. These views are supported by the results of the 1993 Mugford Report entitled The Value of Sport, Ethics and the Control of Performance Enhancing Drugs: A Study in the Australian Sports Community. It noted that:
* athletes perceive the use of drugs for performance enhancement primarily as cheating;
* ASDA is succeeding in creating a climate where athletes are committed to the rules rather than simply obeying them because of the fear of detection, that is, conformity rather than compliance;
* this climate makes use of performance enhancing drugs much harder for athletes to justify; and
* sports people identified sport as having a definite value to society, and clearly drug testing and educational programs undertaken by ASDA protect that value.

While Australia's anti-doping policy is successful we must not become complacent. The amendments in this bill will ensure that our anti-doping programs can operate at an optimum level. The major features of the amendment bill clearly define the objectives of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. These are:
* to deter the use of scheduled drugs or doping methods in sport;
* to encourage the development of programs to educate the sporting community about matters relating to drugs in sport;
* to advocate the international adoption of consistent and effective anti-doping programs; and
* to coordinate the development of a consistent and effective national response to matters relating to drugs in sport.
The functions of the agency as outlined in the bill include:
* development and implementation of drug testing programs;
* advocating the international development and implementation of consistent and effective anti-doping programs; and
* to encourage Australian national sporting organisations, state and territory sporting organisations and professional sporting organisations:

to develop and implement comprehensive and consistent anti‐doping initiatives (including initiatives relating to testing for the use of drugs and education about matters relating to drugs in sport); and
to use the services of the agency and accredited laboratories.
The agency will also:
* develop and implement initiatives that increase the skills and knowledge of people involved in sporting activities about matters relating to drugs in sport;
* advocate and support research inside and outside Australia about drugs in sport;
* implement anti-doping arrangements;
* encourage the establishment of means for the carrying out by departments and authorities of the states and territories, of initiatives relating to drugs in sport; and
* co-operate with those Departments and authorities and with non‐government sporting organisations to implement those initiatives.

This bill has been framed following widespread consultation throughout the sporting and legal communities and other interested parties. This includes the Australian Olympic Committee, the Confederation of Australian Sport, national sporting organisations, the Australia and New Zealand Sports Law Association, and the Privacy Commission.

The legislation reflects the privacy and human rights principles laid down in other Commonwealth legislation. In particular only those who need to have access to information will be informed. The government has also been concerned to protect the rights of athletes and has built into the legislation certain appeal rights to ensure athletes are protected.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT

The administrative and operational expenses related to staff and program costs will be determined annually in the budget. The appropriation to the Australian Sports Drug Agency for 1995‐96 is $3.528 million. This includes an allocation to undertake 2400 `public interest' drug tests on Australian athletes and international athletes who train or compete in this country. It is anticipated that the Australian Sports Drug Agency will generate additional income approaching $500,000 each year from `user pays' education and testing services.

This legislation is clear evidence of this government's commitment to drug free sport. This bill sends a clear message to the sports community in this country and throughout the world that Australia intends to `beat the cheats'. It also sends an important message to our drug free athletes that this government intends to do everything possible to ensure that Australian sportsmen and sportswomen are able to compete in sport which is free from banned doping practices.

This is an issue which has a record of bipartisan support in this parliament, and I am confident that such support will continue with the prompt passage of this important piece of legislation. I am sure that all members want to ensure that our sporting tradition for fair play remains an integral part of our sporting success and that our children can inherit sport free from the use of drugs. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sawford) adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 20 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that the ABC allocates $700 per program for the production of the Western Australian edition of Stateline ; if so, is this level of funding consistent with the ABC's charter obligations with regard to the provision of programming for all Australians.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The ABC has advised that Stateline in each state costs at least $3,500 per week including salaries, labour and cash costs.
This does not include the use of facilities such as studios and labour which are incorporated in the budgets for other ABC news and current affairs programs.

There is a cash budget of $750 per week for Stateline in Western Australia. Normally the cash budget covers costs such as phones, meal allowances, penalty rate and overtime payments plus the actual costs of covering stories such as line bookings, air fares and travel allowance.
In Stateline's case, phone costs are absorbed by other programs. Stateline is broadcast on Friday and compiled Monday to Friday so there are minimal penalty and overtime payments.
If material is needed on weekends or at nights, the footage is shot by already rostered news crews so no extra costs accrues to Stateline .
As Stateline is primarily a studio‐based discussion program, there is limited need to travel for stories and most of subjects for interview are available where seats of government are based.
These issues were taken into account when determining the cash budget and in practice it is proving adequate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service, upon notice, on 27 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Government support the merit principle in the recruitment and promotion of officers of the Australian Public Service (APS); if so, will "an understanding of and demonstrated commitment to the implementation of equal employment opportunity (EEO), occupational health and safety (OH&S) and industrial democracy (ID)" continue to be a mandatory selection criteria for positions in the APS.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government does support the merit principle in the recruitment and promotion of officers in the Australian Public Service (APS).

"An understanding of and demonstrated commitment to the implementation of equal employment opportunity (EEO), occupational health and safety (OH&S) and industrial democracy (ID)" are not and never have been mandatory selection criteria. APS departments and agencies are required under the Public Service Act 1922 to have EEO and ID plans and the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 requires each employer to develop in consultation with relevant union(s) an OH&S policy and Agreement. Agencies as part of their plans may choose to include the above criteria or some similar variant in the selection criteria for positions. I am advised that, in practice, they do.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service, upon notice, on 27 May 1996:

BREAK.PARA: Will the Government maintain the presence of a union delegate on interview panels within the Australian Public Service, if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian Public Service departments and agencies are not required to have union delegates on interview panels.

However, a Departmental Secretary may choose to use a Joint Selection Committee under the provisions of the Public Service Act 1922. Joint Selection Committees provide for a panel convened by a representative of the Merit Protection and Review Agency, with a nominee of the Secretary and a nominee of the relevant staff organisation. Such arrangements are used for selection exercises mainly where there are large numbers of vacancies to be filled and overcome the need for possible promotion appeal hearings later.
The question of whether these arrangements should be changed will be considered in the context of an examination of the Public Service Act.
